author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Join the Club, Save Some Money
description: Safari deals at Costco; discount lift tickets at Sam’s Club. Add AARP and AAA into the mix of memberships that offer savings on travel.
content: When Ashlee Laird, 32, a high school adviser in Houston, was planning her honeymoon to Italy in 2015, a friend suggested she look at Costco Travel, the travel division of Costco Wholesale’s retail membership club that operates warehouse-scale stores. Through Costco, she booked an eight-day trip to Rome and Florence for two for $3,800, including round-trip flights, hotels, daily breakfast, private cars to and from the Italian airports, first-class train tickets between the cities and $400 to spend on tours, which they used to see the Vatican and the Colosseum and take a pizza-making class.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor and Matt Stevens
title: Ready for South Carolina? This Week in the 2020 Race
description: Joe Biden is looking to win Saturday’s primary as some Democrats worry about Bernie Sanders’s momentum coming out of the Nevada caucuses.
content: It’s Primary Day (again)! As voters in South Carolina cast their ballots, let’s catch you up on what happened this week and get you ready for Super Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Junya Watanabe: Fall 2020
description: See the looks from the Junya Watanabe: Fall 2020 Collection.
content: See the looks from the Junya Watanabe: Fall 2020 Collection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon can hear a pin drop.
content: ACROSTIC — We obviously never get a bad acrostic puzzle, but this is one of the ones that I think of as perfect, the kind that I would gladly push on someone new to the game. The passage is lovely, from a book by Steven Halpern called “Sound Healing: The Music and Sounds That Make Us Whole.” The clues are packed with sly references to the topic at hand, many of them rapturously sneaky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: They Recovered From the Coronavirus. Were They Infected Again?
description: In a few cases, patients again tested positive for the virus after they were no longer ill. But little is known about the virus, and it’s possible that testing flaws may be to blame.
content: Can people who recover from a bout with the new coronavirus become infected again — and again?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Junot Díaz
title: James McBride’s ‘Deacon King Kong’ is a Supercharged Urban Farce Lit Up by Thunderbolts of Rage
description: The National Book Award-winning author’s deeply felt new novel is an American crime story, just not the kind on TV.
content: DEACON KING KONG By James McBride
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters and Maggie Haberman
title: Making Pitch to Voters, Bloomberg Peddles His Experience in a Crisis
description: Michael R. Bloomberg, trying to convey the competence and cool-headedness he says are missing in the White House, will air a new three-minute commercial nationally on Sunday.
content: CLARKSVILLE, Tenn. — Hobbled by lackluster debate performances and with time running short, Michael R. Bloomberg is trying to refocus his presidential campaign on his experience dealing with disasters as the mayor of New York, hoping to draw a stark contrast with President Trump’s handling of the coronavirus and the managerial records of some of his Democratic opponents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francesca Donner
title: Life Inside an Afghan Women’s Prison
description: The photographer Kiana Hayeri documented mothers inside an Afghan prison. Here’s what it was like.
content: — Parisa, an inmate at Herat Women’s Prison
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff
title: Kept at the Hospital on Coronavirus Fears, Now Facing Large Medical Bills
description: Care was mandated by the government, but it’s not clear who has to pay.
content: Frank Wucinski and his 3-year-old daughter, Annabel, are among the dozens of Americans the government has flown back to the country from Wuhan, China, and put under quarantine to check for signs of coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Wellons
title: From Blackhawk to Brain Surgery to Bride
description: So many people came together to save this one girl’s life, and her chance to grow, to find happiness, to find love.
content: On a blustery, rainy Saturday nearly two decades ago, in my first year of practice, I went to my office after rounds, put my feet up on my desk, took a sip of lukewarm coffee and leaned back in my chair to relax after a busy morning. Within seconds, I felt the pager clipped to my belt vibrate. I set my mug down on the desk and called the number back. An emergency room doctor from another hospital immediately picked up and identified himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff
title: Kept at the Hospital on Coronavirus Fears, Now Facing Large Medical Bills
description: Care was mandated by the government, but it’s not clear who has to pay.
content: Frank Wucinski and his 3-year-old daughter, Annabel, are among the dozens of Americans the government has flown back to the country from Wuhan, China, and put under quarantine to check for signs of coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annalee Newitz
title: How to Be a Smart Coronavirus Prepper
description: Instead of freaking ourselves out, we need to plan for a difficult future every day.
content: The first case of “community transmitted” Covid-19 in the United States popped up just a few miles north of my home in San Francisco. That means the person who is sick with the new coronavirus has no known connection to China or travelers from there — she got it from someone in her local Northern California community. My community. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has said the arrival of Covid-19 is “inevitable.” Because the disease has an incubation period of at least two weeks, I could be surrounded by the infected and not know. Hell, I could be infected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel L. Harris and Lisa Tarchak
title: Shifting Fervor, and Favorites, in the Presidential Race
description: Readers share their choice for president and how it has changed in recent weeks.
content: This Tuesday is the big one — Super Tuesday, when 14 states, and American Samoa, will vote in Democratic primaries and caucuses. We recently asked our columnists to make their best cases for the six strongest Democratic candidates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ilana Kaplan
title: Mandy Moore Is Ready to Be Heard
description: After a quiet decade and a painful divorce, the singer has a new studio album, a whole new set of fans and a favorite 2020 candidate. (His name is Pete.)
content: As they neared the turn of the millennium, and steeled themselves for the Y2K bug, Americans faced a critical question: Whom would they crown the teen queen of pop?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Michael Bloomberg Will Address Coronavirus in Prime-Time TV Ad
description: Seeking to draw a direct contrast with President Trump, Mr. Bloomberg will deliver a three-minute prerecorded address on the coronavirus outbreak in an ad on network television Sunday night.
content: Seeking to draw a direct contrast with President Trump and present himself as the best Democratic alternative, Michael R. Bloomberg will deliver a three-minute prerecorded address on the coronavirus outbreak in an ad on network television Sunday night, his campaign announced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Top U.K. Civil Servant Quits and Vows to Sue, Accusing Minister of ‘Vicious’ Behavior
description: Philip Rutnam said his treatment by Home Secretary Priti Patel was part of a pattern of abuse in the government, and accused her of fostering a climate of “fear.”
content: LONDON — An extraordinary public row broke out in Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s new government on Saturday, with a top civil servant quitting amid allegations that he was bullied and mistreated by one of Mr. Johnson’s closest political allies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: Malaysia’s Premier, Mahathir Mohamad, Is Ousted in a Surprising Turn
description: Mr. Mahathir, 94, who has towered over the country’s politics for decades, was replaced by Muhyiddin Yassin, a onetime ally whom he accused of betrayal.
content: Mahathir Mohamad, 94, has dominated Malaysian politics for decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley, Motoko Rich and Makiko Inoue
title: In Graying Japan, Many Are Vulnerable but Few Are Being Tested
description: The coronavirus is particularly dangerous to older people, but the Japanese authorities have maintained strict constraints on testing for it.
content: TOKYO — My Home Harumi, a nursing home in central Tokyo, is on lockdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Maria Sharapova’s Future: Architecture and Candy, but Not Coaching Tennis
description: A playing comeback is also a no: “I promise everyone.”
content: The exit interview had just about ended last week when I asked Maria Sharapova if she would consider coaching in retirement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell
title: ‘Where Do I Find Your Hand Sanitizer?’ Sorry, We Have None.
description: As shoppers look for products to help protect against an outbreak, they are increasingly finding empty shelves.
content: CEDAR KNOLLS, N.J. — Many shoppers at the local Walmart had the same question on Friday morning: “Where do I find your hand sanitizer?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango and Thomas Fuller
title: In Prosperous California, Anxiety Over Inequality Abounds
description: As millions of Californians prepare to vote on Super Tuesday, the state’s affordability crisis is weighing heavily on their minds.
content: BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — Mark Marquez, a retired Border Patrol agent, had hoped to keep his extended family intact in the same part of central California where his parents and grandparents had worked the watermelon fields.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember and Shane Goldmacher
title: Sanders Looks to Topple Warren in Her Home State
description: A victory in Massachusetts would not just give Mr. Sanders a significant share of the state’s 91 delegates but also inflict a symbolic blow to his closest ideological rival.
content: SPRINGFIELD, Mass. — Bernie Sanders landed in Elizabeth Warren’s home state on Friday night, stood before thousands of screaming fans and asked them to help him win it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Rogers
title: ‘There Is No Evil,’ About Executions in Iran, Wins Top Prize at Berlin Film Festival
description: Mohammad Rasoulof, who was sentenced to prison in Iran for “spreading propaganda,” directed the film in secret and was not able to attend the ceremony.
content: BERLIN — The Golden Bear for best feature film at the Berlin International Film Festival was given on Saturday to “There Is No Evil,” a drama by the Iranian director Mohammad Rasoulof centering on people who carry out executions in the Islamic Republic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Knvul Sheikh
title: Surgeon General Urges the Public to Stop Buying Face Masks
description: “Seriously people,” the surgeon general said on Twitter, warning that a run on the masks could risk a shortage harmful to public health professionals.
content: The surgeon general on Saturday urged the public to stop buying masks, warning that it won’t help against the spread of the coronavirus but will take away important resources from health care professionals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mae Jemison
title: I Was the First Woman of Color in Space. Here’s What Katherine Johnson Means to Me.
description: In my years in NASA and since, I’ve seen the untapped potential of women, particularly women of color.
content: Two years after I joined NASA in 1987, I was preparing for a trip to Brazil to help the United States Information Service celebrate the 20th anniversary of the Apollo 11 moon landing. The souvenir posters I would give out referred to the “first American men on the moon.” I suggested it would be more appropriate if they read “first humans on the moon.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman and Karl Russell
title: Aging, Rising, Brainy, Booming: Super Tuesday Economies Pose Wider Test
description: The 14 states can be sorted into four general types. (Minnesota and Virginia may be more alike than you think.)
content: The first few contests in the Democratic presidential primary race have been fought in states that are small and somewhat quirky economically. There aren’t many states where voters care as much about ethanol subsidies as they do in Iowa, or where culinary unions wield as much power as in Nevada.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Make This Bacon-y, Spicy Fried Rice Tonight
description: One-pot braised chicken, crispy fried rice, and more recipes.
content: The week’s most popular dishes include Alison Roman’s salmon with whole lemon dressing, Melissa Clark’s crispy fried rice with bacon and cabbage (above), and Gabrielle Hamilton’s gravlax. Find more recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Adriana Ramić
title: What’s at Stake in the South Carolina Primary
description: Today’s South Carolina primary could be Joe Biden’s best chance to turn his fortunes around after dismal finishes in Iowa and New Hampshire and a distant second in Nevada.
content: Today’s South Carolina primary could be Joe Biden’s best chance to turn his fortunes around after dismal finishes in Iowa and New Hampshire and a distant second in Nevada.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Comme Des Garçons: Fall 2020
description: See the looks from the Comme Des Garçons: Fall 2020 Collection.
content: See the looks from the Comme Des Garçons: Fall 2020 Collection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donald G. McNeil Jr
title: When an Epidemic Looms, Gagging Scientists Is a Terrible Idea
description: In an epidemic, suppression of bad news costs lives and eventually angers the public. The White House is in danger of repeating the error.
content: Many times in many countries, political leaders have tried to censor health officials and play down the risks of infection just as epidemics approached.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: M.I.T. Researchers Cast Doubt on Bolivian Election Fraud
description: An international audit said officials had engaged in lies and manipulation to assure victory for Evo Morales. Academics at M.I.T.’s Election Data and Science Lab questioned that finding.
content: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — Researchers from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology have cast doubt on a claim that Bolivian officials engaged in fraud to help Evo Morales, the longtime president, win re-election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘S.N.L.’ and Young Dylan
description: John Mulaney hosts “S.N.L.”, while the child rapper Young Dylan debuts his new show on Nickelodeon.
content: SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE 11:30 p.m. on NBC. John Mulaney had to postpone a show in Toronto because he was “drafted” to host this episode, Lorne Michaels wrote in an apology to Mulaney’s Canadian fans. (Mulaney weighed in: “I’m afraid of Lorne, so I do what he says.”) This is the comedian’s third time hosting the show. He’s joined by the musical guest David Byrne, the former frontman of Talking Heads, who just wrapped up the first run of his critically acclaimed Broadway show “American Utopia.” (For those who missed the stage run, don’t fret — Byrne will reprise the production in the fall, and Spike Lee has announced that he will direct a film version to be released later this year.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Is This Coronavirus ‘the Big One’?
description: For decades, experts’ warnings to prepare have gone unheeded.
content: Alice Wolowitz, a student nurse, began her shift at a hospital one morning in Philadelphia. She fell sick during the shift, rapidly declined and was dead that night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Trump Makes Us Ill
description: Going viral is not a good thing this time.
content: Donald Trump was right.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Live Analysis: South Carolina Primary
description: Follow live coverage and analysis from Times reporters.
content: Follow live coverage and analysis from Times reporters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Former Police Officer Pleads Guilty in Russian Roulette Killing of Another Officer
description: Nathaniel R. Hendren, who was an officer in St. Louis, was accused of fatally shooting his female colleague, Katlyn Alix, while on duty in his apartment in 2019.
content: A former St. Louis police officer accused of killing another officer while playing Russian roulette pleaded guilty on Friday and was sentenced to seven years in prison, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Can David Ross Bring the Magic of 2016 Back to the Cubs?
description: He was the elder statesman on the roster when the Chicago Cubs finally won the World Series. Four years later, they’re counting on Ross, now the manager, to reverse their slide down the standings.
content: MESA, Ariz. — The final swing of David Ross’s career produced a home run in Game 7 of the 2016 World Series. His Chicago Cubs teammates carried him off the field on their shoulders, and it was not the first time he had experienced glory. Three years earlier, as the Boston Red Sox catcher, Ross squeezed the final strikeout to end the season as a champion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: Why a Coronavirus Recession Would Be So Hard to Contain
description: A supply shock is not a problem our usual economic tools are particularly good at solving. But it’s the one we face.
content: It looks more and more likely that the novel form of coronavirus will do meaningful economic damage to the United States. Stock and bond prices already suggest that the outbreak could halt the longest expansion on record and even send the nation into recession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced and Kate Conger
title: Hedge Fund May Push for Ouster of Jack Dorsey as Twitter’s C.E.O.
description: The activist hedge fund Elliott Management has taken a sizable stake in Twitter and called for changes at the social network.
content: One of Wall Street’s most powerful activist hedge funds has taken a stake in Twitter and intends to shake up the social network — including by potentially calling for the replacement of its founder, Jack Dorsey, as chief executive, two people briefed on the matter said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: How South Carolina Could Change the Democratic Race
description: Many black voters rallied around Joe Biden in Saturday’s primary, eager to send a message that their views of electability are not shaped by predominantly white states like Iowa.
content: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — In 2008 and 2016, black voters in South Carolina’s presidential primary set the last two Democratic nominees on their way, backing Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton by huge margins. Rival candidates never managed to catch up in the race for delegates to clinch the nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Karen Weise
title: Washington State Declares Emergency Amid Coronavirus Death and Illnesses at Nursing Home
description: A person in the Seattle area died. Two others tested positive for the virus in a long term care center where dozens of people have reported feeling ill.
content: SEATTLE — Concerns about the coronavirus intensified across the Pacific Northwest on Saturday, after a person from the Seattle area died and as two new cases emerged inside a nursing care center in Kirkland, Wash., where dozens of other people were reported to be feeling sick.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: The Driving Force in Irish Politics? Finding a Decent Place to Live
description: A severe housing crisis has made life unbearable for many young people, who turned in droves to the previously toxic Sinn Fein party in this month’s election.
content: DUBLIN — After Ireland’s economy cratered in 2008, the friends and fellow activists watched a mass exodus of young people do what the Irish had always done in times of crisis: Leave the country for more prosperous shores.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs and Sheri Fink
title: How Prepared Is the U.S. for a Coronavirus Outbreak?
description: The country is better positioned than most but still could face critical shortages of respirators and masks. Hospitals have triage plans in place. State and local governments have broad powers to quarantine.
content: In 2005, the federal government sought to assess how a respiratory-related pandemic might play out in the United States. Its report estimated that a severe influenza pandemic would require mechanical ventilators for 740,000 critically ill people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denise Grady
title: How Does the Coronavirus Compare to the Flu?
description: As new cases appear on the West Coast, some — including the president — see comparisons to the seasonal flu. Here’s a close look at the differences.
content: Is this new coronavirus really a serious danger? Doesn’t the flu kill more people?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump Calls for Calm on Virus and Expands Travel Restrictions
description: The announcement included elevated warnings against travel to specific regions in Italy and South Korea, and came after the U.S. recorded its first coronavirus death: a person near Seattle.
content: President Trump sought on Saturday to more aggressively address the coronavirus after weeks of confusion over his administration’s response, urging public calm and issuing new foreign travel warnings and restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Frank Type
description: Andrew J. Ries brings us a high-toned Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Andrew J. Ries is a regular in the weekend rotation, and when I see his name on a grid I expect a lot of puns and a pretty good challenge over all. On the first count, I think today’s puzzle is more straightforward than cheeky; on the second count, I took awhile to work through the center of the grid and felt very satisfied (and edified) at the finish. It might have just been my usual suggestibility, but I got a bit overtaken by “Weltschmerz” today. I can’t blame Mr. Ries for my own ENNUI — this is a good, crunchy solve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: ‘Border Security Is Also Health Security,’ Trump Says at Rally as Coronavirus Fears Grow
description: While members of his administration tried to convey a calm and steady response, President Trump hosted another free-form political rally where he accused his enemies of stoking panic.
content: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — Larry Kudlow, the president’s chief economic adviser, stood in the White House briefing room on Friday urging the public — and the plunging financial markets — not to panic over the coronavirus outbreak, while Vice President Mike Pence spread a similar message to officials and residents at an event in Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Isaac-Goizé
title: In Paris, a New Fashion Nexus Comes With a Canteen
description: L’Epi d’Or, long a neighborhood favorite, has new celebrity chef owners but the same 1930s style.
content: PARIS — Forget Avenue Montaigne. The Les Halles neighborhood — the area in the First Arrondissement once nicknamed “the Belly of Paris” for its sprawling food market — is about to become a magnet for French fashion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: At CPAC, It’s Now an All-Trump Show
description: At the annual gathering of conservatives, one Republican was conspicuously absent among the Trump supporters — Mitt Romney. The conference organizer said he had been disinvited.
content: OXON HILL, Md. — Donald J. Trump was still a New York businessman when he was booed at the Conservative Political Action Conference in 2015 after he proposed fighting ISIS with troops on the ground in the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Goldfarb
title: It’s Your Birthday and You Can Do What You Want To
description: Four ideas for how to solve the problem of your birthday.
content: Throughout much of human history, people didn’t celebrate their birthdays. Many people didn’t even know when their birthday was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Goldfarb
title: It’s Your Birthday and You Can Do What You Want To
description: Four ideas for how to solve the problem of your birthday.
content: Throughout much of human history, people didn’t celebrate their birthdays. Many people didn’t even know when their birthday was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: The Hidden History of Slavery That Surrounds Us
description: Most of the sites of the slave trade are unmarked, including the auction sites where families were torn apart.
content: For hundreds of years, enslaved people were bought and sold in America. Today most of the sites of this trade are forgotten. As part of The 1619 Project, Anne C. Bailey, a professor of history at Binghamton University, wrote about her research into slave auctions for a New York Times Magazine article titled “They Sold Human Beings Here.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: Lee Phillip Bell, Soap Opera Creator and Talk Show Host, Dies at 91
description: She and her husband developed “The Young and the Restless” and “The Bold and the Beautiful” while she also worked as a broadcast journalist in Chicago.
content: Lee Phillip Bell, a co-creator of two of daytime television’s most successful and enduring soap operas, “The Young and the Restless” and “The Bold and the Beautiful,” died on Tuesday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Here’s How Landlords Are Getting Around New Rent Laws
description: With changes to state laws making it harder to increase rent in stabilized apartments, landlords are finding creative ways to keep the money flowing.
content: Q: I live in a rental building on the Upper East Side. Recently, a tenant vacated an inexpensive rent-stabilized unit. Rather than list the apartment, the landlord has kept it vacant for months. Some tenants speculate that he is waiting for the tenant in the adjacent market-rate apartment to move out so he can combine the two units, creating one large market-rate apartment. Is this legal under the new rent laws, which prohibit landlords from destabilizing apartments when tenants vacate?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Are Men Not Listening to Women?
description: We published a plea by Kimberly Probolus for men to become better listeners. Readers offer their personal experiences and advice.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Seeking Gender Parity in Your Letters
description: Readers both applaud The Times’s effort to publish more letters from women and call it “political correctness run amok.”
content: Editors’ Note: Thomas Feyer, the letters editor of The Times, recused himself from selecting responses to his own article and delegated that role to another editor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Actors Walk Out After Roman Polanski Wins Best Director at France’s Oscars
description: The director, who has a history of accusations of sexual assault, won for the film “J’accuse.”
content: LONDON — Roman Polanski, the film director who fled the United States in 1978 while awaiting sentencing for unlawful sexual intercourse with a minor, was a big winner Friday night at the Césars, France’s equivalent of the Academy Awards, leading several actors to walk out of the ceremony in outrage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh
title: F.D.A. Expands Coronavirus Testing in the United States
description: The agency announced that it would allow hundreds of labs to test for the virus, circumventing the C.D.C.’s centralized testing system and making it likely that cases will be detected faster.
content: The Food and Drug Administration announced Saturday that testing for the coronavirus would be greatly expanded in the United States, giving laboratories and hospitals around the country the go-ahead to conduct tests that had until now been severely limited to those analyzed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Flegenheimer and Katie Glueck
title: Joe Biden’s Last Stand
description: He loves South Carolina. He said he will win South Carolina. He spent the days before the primary reminding South Carolina why it should love him back.
content: HEMINGWAY, S.C. — Joe Biden was moving — two buttons unbuttoned, sunglasses indoors, a God-love-ya in every pot — and the finger-guns would be holstered for no one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Maxim Babenko
title: Russia Gets Its Disneyland, a Cold War Dream Come True
description: Developers are banking on attracting Moscow’s rising middle class. “But will they sell emotions, like Disneyland?” a mother of two girls asks.
content: MOSCOW — A young girl finds a magic necklace made of mushrooms, but then an evil gnome steals it. Adventure ensues. According to her creators, Alfreya, the hero of a new children’s book who was conceived for Russia’s first theme park, is “an ordinary girl 10 to 12 years old with large, thoughtful eyes.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Maxim Babenko
title: Russia Gets Its Disneyland, a Cold War Dream Come True
description: Developers are banking on attracting Moscow’s rising middle class. “But will they sell emotions, like Disneyland?” a mother of two girls asks.
content: MOSCOW — A young girl finds a magic necklace made of mushrooms, but then an evil gnome steals it. Adventure ensues. According to her creators, Alfreya, the hero of a new children’s book who was conceived for Russia’s first theme park, is “an ordinary girl 10 to 12 years old with large, thoughtful eyes.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Celine Dion, a Consummate Professional, With Winks Galore
description: At the first of a series of New York-area arena dates on her Courage World Tour, the pop diva was fully in command of her glorious voice — and the crowd gathered to bask in it.
content: No matter what she sings, Celine Dion makes it her own. Toward the end of her show at Barclays Center in Brooklyn on Friday night, she performed a megamix that included the ultra-recognizable likes of David Bowie’s “Let’s Dance,” Queen’s “Another One Bites the Dust,” Prince’s “Kiss,” Ike and Tina Turner’s “River Deep, Mountain High” and “Lady Marmalade,” made famous by Labelle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: For Boris Johnson, Britain’s Baby Boom Starts at 10 Downing
description: The prime minister announced that he and his partner, Carrie Symonds, were expecting a child. It’s the first for her. For Johnson? Well, that’s not so clear.
content: LONDON — Of all the glad tidings that Prime Minister Boris Johnson promised would flow from Brexit, one of the most far-fetched was a baby boom. But at least in his own case, Mr. Johnson has actually delivered on that pledge.
source.name: The New York Times

title: South Carolina 2020 Primary: Live Results
description: Detailed results and maps from the South Carolina primary election.
content: Detailed results and maps from the South Carolina primary election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman and Talya Minsberg
title: Rupp and Tuliamuk Win Olympic Trials Marathon
description: Abdirahman, Riley, Seidel and Kipyego also book tickets to Tokyo 2020. Linden fourth.
content: ATLANTA — There is an old saying that goes with running the marathon distance of 26.2 miles: 20 miles is about halfway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nellie Bowles
title: The Pied Pipers of the Dirtbag Left Want to Lead Everyone to Bernie Sanders
description: Many listeners would never repeat what these podcast hosts say. So why do they desperately want to hear from them?
content: IOWA CITY — The people in the crowd were angry, and “Chapo Trap House” wanted them to stay that way. The five hosts of the popular socialist podcast wanted everyone to know they had all been lied to. About everything.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun and Lam Yik Fei
title: For Seoul’s Poor, Class Strife in ‘Parasite’ Is Daily Reality
description: Like the family in the Oscar-winning film, many in Seoul’s so-called dirt-spoon class dwell in basements far below the rich. “Those living up there must look down on people like me like pigs.”
content: SEOUL, South Korea — The sunlight peeks into Kim Ssang-seok’s home for just half an hour a day. When he opens his only window and looks up, he sees the wheels of passing cars. Mr. Kim dries his clothes ​and shoes ​in the sunless inside because of thieves outside. He wages a constant battle against cockroaches and the sewer smell emanating from the low-ceilinged, musty space that is his toilet and laundry room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: Taliban and U.S. Strike Deal to Withdraw American Troops From Afghanistan
description: After more than a year of talks, the agreement lays out the beginning of the end of the United States’ longest war. But many obstacles remain.
content: DOHA, Qatar — The United States signed a deal with the Taliban on Saturday that sets the stage to end America’s longest war — the nearly two-decade-old conflict in Afghanistan that began after the Sept. 11 attacks, killed tens of thousands of people, vexed three White House administrations and left mistrust and uncertainty on all sides.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Photos From America’s Longest War
description: A visual chronicle of the Afghanistan conflict.
content: Soon after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, the United States military’s attention turned to Afghanistan, where Al Qaeda’s leaders were based. Many knew an invasion was sure to come.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: 2020 Hopefuls Invoke Obama to Lure Voters
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, February 29, 2020.
content: “I think it would be political malpractice for any of the candidates not to closely associate themselves with the most popular person in the Democratic Party.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Noir Kei Ninomiya: Fall 2020
description: See the looks from the Noir Kei Ninomiya: Fall 2020 Collection.
content: See the looks from the Noir Kei Ninomiya: Fall 2020 Collection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Gerald Krone, a Negro Ensemble Company Founder, Dies at 86
description: He provided the administrative know-how that got the theater troupe off the ground in 1967. That he was white drew some criticism.
content: Gerald S. Krone, a theater manager and producer who in 1967 joined with Douglas Turner Ward and Robert Hooks to found the Negro Ensemble Company, a New York theater troupe that championed black writers, actors and themes in what was then a largely white theatrical landscape, died on Feb. 20 at his home in Philadelphia. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Altuzarra: Fall 2020
description: See the looks from the Altuzarra: Fall 2020 Collection.
content: See the looks from the Altuzarra: Fall 2020 Collection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Annie Karni
title: Trump Accuses Media and Democrats of Exaggerating Coronavirus Threat
description: The accusations came as other elements of the federal government moved to head off a broader wave of infections like those in China.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump and members of his administration mobilized on Friday to confront the threat of the coronavirus — not just the outbreak, but the news media and the Democrats they accused of exaggerating its danger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raúl Vilchis
title: M.L.S. Brings Chicharito Closer to Mexico. But Maybe Not Close Enough.
description: Javier Hernández’s decision to join the Los Angeles Galaxy was a coup for M.L.S., but back in his native Mexico, critics wondered why he hadn’t just come home.
content: The most explosive announcement of Major League Soccer’s off-season this year came in the form of an emotional, intimate moment shared on YouTube.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nu Wexler
title: Joe Biden Needs a Win in South Carolina. Will He Get It?
description: Politics still move at a different pace there, and it’s a place where loyalty can outweigh ideology.
content: When Joe Biden was considering running for president last spring, progressive activists circulated a video clip of him delivering the eulogy at Strom Thurmond’s funeral in 2003. In spring 2019, Mr. Biden delivered another senatorial eulogy at Fritz Hollings’s funeral, and rivals pounced again (in both cases, for praising the onetime segregationist senators).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery
title: Coronavirus Fears Reverberate Across Global Economy
description: The stock market had its worst week since 2008, signaling that one of the longest expansions in history could be ending. Policymakers said they were ready to act.
content: Investors, fearing that the spread of the coronavirus is tipping the global economy into a recession, handed the stock market its largest weekly loss since the 2008 financial crisis on Friday amid worries that one of the longest economic expansions in history may be coming to an end.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Who’s on the U.S. Coronavirus Task Force
description: Several of the nation’s top health officials are among those sitting on an advisory panel formed by President Trump.
content: President Trump formed a coronavirus task force in late January, and members have been meeting regularly. But as the virus began to spread around the globe and infections were confirmed in the United States, Mr. Trump named Vice President Mike Pence as his point person at the end of February, and more administration officials were added to the panel. Among them are internationally known AIDS experts; a former drug executive; infectious disease doctors; and the former attorney general of Virginia.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Hermes: Fall 2020
description: See the looks from the Hermes: Fall 2020 Collection.
content: See the looks from the Hermes: Fall 2020 Collection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Here Comes the Coronavirus Pandemic
description: Now, after many fire drills, the world may be facing a real fire.
content: Back in 2002, when the SARS virus made its fateful leap from bats to civet cats to humans, global health experts warned that the ensuing outbreak was a harbinger of things to come: Climate change and globalization were conspiring with an array of other forces to make it much easier for old animal diseases to morph into new human ones. It was only a matter of time before one of those diseases proved truly catastrophic. The world could avert the worst consequences if it started planning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Rosenthal
title: We Don’t Really Know How Many People Have Coronavirus
description: In an era when we get flash-flood warnings on phones, why is data on the new coronavirus so limited?
content: It has been nearly three months since the first cases of a new coronavirus pneumonia appeared in Wuhan, China, and it is now a global outbreak. And yet, despite over 80,000 infections worldwide (most of them in China), the world still doesn’t have a clear picture of some of the most basic information about this outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tess Taylor
title: Following Dorothea Lange’s Notebooks
description: The Californian photographer known for her images of the Great Depression is a guide to the complexity of the present.
content: HOLTVILLE, Ca. — It’s late when I check into the Barbara Worth Country Club, 600 miles southeast of my home in the Bay Area. Spare rooms border dark fields, a dry golf course and a web of open irrigation troughs that help make Imperial County one of the biggest agricultural producers in California. Holtville calls itself the carrot capital of the world, and even now, after this season’s harvest, stray carrot tops bolt, blooming to seed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theresa Brown and Leah Nash
title: Who Will Care For Society’s Forgotten?
description: Housecall Providers, an organization in Portland, Ore., provides end-of-life care for the city’s most vulnerable residents.
content: PORTLAND, Ore. — Homeless people, when most of us think of them at all, seem to have no past and no future. It is hard to picture them as children who went to school, played games and, I hope, were loved. It is equally hard to imagine that they age, the way all of us do, and get sick, possibly very sick, just like the rest of us. We even rarely think about how they receive medical care — and yet how and whether we treat these patients, especially at the end of their lives, is a moral measuring stick that is all too often missing in our discussions about health care in America.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Who’s on the U.S. Coronavirus Task Force
description: Several of the nation’s top health officials are among those sitting on an advisory panel formed by President Trump.
content: President Trump formed a coronavirus task force in late January, and members have been meeting regularly. But as the virus began to spread around the globe and infections were confirmed in the United States, Mr. Trump named Vice President Mike Pence as his point person at the end of February, and more administration officials were added to the panel. Among them are internationally known AIDS experts; a former drug executive; infectious disease doctors; and the former attorney general of Virginia.
source.name: The New York Times

title: South Carolina Primary Forecast
description: The Times plans to make estimates after 7 p.m. Eastern.
content: The Times plans to make estimates after 7 p.m. Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Joe Coulombe, Who Founded Trader Joe’s, Dies at 89
description: “Equal parts gourmet shop, discount warehouse and Tiki trading post,” his stores caught on in Southern California and, eventually, beyond.
content: Joseph Coulombe, who in 1967 parsed a few cultural trends, added his retail instincts and created Trader Joe’s, the popular grocery chain known for unusual foods, a generous wine selection and a laid-back atmosphere, died on Friday at his home in Pasadena, Calif. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Russell Goldman
title: 4 Takeaways From the U.S. Deal With the Taliban
description: The U.S. has agreed to gradually pull troops from Afghanistan, in exchange for the Taliban’s promise not to let terrorists return. A difficult process lies ahead.
content: DOHA, Qatar — The agreement just signed by American and Taliban negotiators opens the way for direct negotiations between the insurgents and other Afghans, including the country’s government, on a political future after the United States ends its military presence. The negotiations could also result in a cease-fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manny Fernandez
title: For Migrants at the Border, a Day of Hopes Uplifted and Dashed
description: Crowds of migrants headed for border crossings after an appeals court ruled against the Trump administration’s “Remain in Mexico” policy for asylum seekers. But their hopes were short-lived.
content: CIUDAD JUÁREZ, Mexico — At first, the people at the Good Samaritan migrant shelter who have had few reasons to cheer did precisely that. With news that many of them could soon be on their way to the United States, they applauded and embraced in the outdoor plaza, where sagging clotheslines intrude onto the basketball court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: For American Military, Coronavirus Is an Enemy to Be Fought
description: The military’s first active-duty case, in South Korea, has commanders preparing a battle plan. But steps meant to stave off the virus may also compromise training and readiness.
content: The commander of an American military post near the center of a coronavirus outbreak in South Korea delivered the sobering news to his troops in warriors’ terms: “We had a breach in our perimeter.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Carlotta Gall
title: Erdogan Says, ‘We Opened the Doors,’ and Clashes Erupt as Migrants Head for Europe
description: Thousands of migrants in Turkey faced off with riot police at the Greek border, and the Turkish leader lashed out at the E.U., saying it had not helped him manage a growing crisis in northern Syria.
content: KASTANIES, Greece — With tear gas clouding the air, thousands of migrants trying to reach Europe clashed with riot police on the Greek border with Turkey on Saturday morning, signaling a new and potentially volatile phase in the migration crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Jack Ewing
title: Coronavirus Tests Limits of Central Bank Firepower
description: Investors are looking to the Federal Reserve and its peers as markets swoon and infections rise. They’re short on ammunition.
content: Federal Reserve officials and their global counterparts are staring down an economic threat unlike any they have ever faced, as markets look to them to contain the fallout from a rapidly spreading virus with limited ammunition and tools ill-suited to deal with broken supply chains and quarantined consumers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: After 18 Years, Is This Afghan Peace, or Just a Way Out?
description: Afghanistan has gone from being the “good war” that the United States must win to the longstanding burden that, like the British, the Soviets and a series of others, it now seeks to unload.
content: President Trump has left no doubt that his first priority in Afghanistan is a peace treaty that would enable him to claim that he is fulfilling his vow to withdraw American troops.
source.name: The New York Times
